abstracts.cdata!:
The Participatory Privatization of
            Irrigation Management and Investment Project for Turkey had
            the following ratings: the outcome was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was substantial, and the Bank and borrower
            performance were both satisfactory. The lessons learned
            indicate that the original project concept involved only
            equipment for Operation and Maintenance (O&M), with
            rehabilitation of irrigation schemes added later. Because
            they are being given increased responsibility for managing
            and funding O&M, Water Users' Organization (WUOs)
            need effective training in management, finance, water
            distribution techniques, and rehabilitation priorities, as
            well as other areas. Functioning within a new paradigm,
            State Hydraulic Works (DSI) needs to reorient its mission to
            more explicitly focus on WUO support, and it might require
            training in the modalities of its relationships with WUOs.
            The Participatory Privatization of Irrigation Management and
            Investment Project (PPIMIP) had little or no identification
            of meaningful monitoring indicators, establishment of
            initial benchmarks, or systematic data collection. The pilot
            drip irrigation component was probably overlooked by General
            Directorate of Rural Services (GDRS) also due to the
            relatively small amount of funds allocated and due to the
            prominent role the other implementing agency.
